utterances: Goolsbee says that is not an accurate reflection of what he said in that meeting.

He said, he stressed to them that Obama has concerns about NAFTA, but that Obama believes in free trade, but that he feels it has to be revisited, the agreement, to address environmental and labor provisions and to take into account what it's meant for workers, like those in Ohio.
And this discussion about positions on NAFTA seems to be aimed squarely at the voters in Ohio, but you are both in Texas now with Senators Clinton and Obama.
Does the NAFTA issue have the same importance there that it does in Ohio?
It certainly doesn't.
And what we've seen in the final days with Hillary Clinton, two very different messages when she has been in Texas, when she has been in Ohio.

And in Texas, we'll see what she says in these last few stops, but so far much more about foreign policy, much more tapping into people's patriotism and also their fears about terrorism and the world, and suggesting that she is much more prepared to be commander in chief than Barack Obama.
So going after her opponent, but in a very different way with a different message in these two states.
And, Don Gonyea, how is Barack Obama trying to steer the discussion away from this question about the NAFTA meeting?
Well, there are direct appeals to Hispanic voters here in Texas, obviously an important part of the voting public here.
So we're seeing those kinds of pitches.

Senator Obama is meeting with veterans groups and talking to people about the Veterans Affairs Administration and the kind of treatment that wounded veterans and veterans with post-traumatic stress disorder receive when they get back from someplace like Iraq.
You know, this last day before these big primaries in Ohio and Texas, there is a lot of posturing on both sides about expectations for tomorrow.
David Greene, why don't you tell us what's going on the Clinton campaign?
The Clinton campaign in public is talking about being very confident that they can win these two states.

But in private, you know, they say that they feel more confident in Ohio, they're worried about the sort of strange voting system in Texas that involves caucusing, which has been an advantage to Obama.
But they're saying if they win Ohio, perhaps they can use the message that this is a really important presidential swing state in the general election.
If they beat Obama here, that sends a message.
But certainly they're going to have a lot of thinking to do.
And Don Gonyea, what about the expectations on Obama's side?
For the Obama campaign, it's all about the delegate count.
They are hoping for a win in Texas.
They think they have a very good chance there.
There are indications that maybe they're ready for a loss in Ohio.
Senator Obama pulled out of there, and had a night in Chicago before heading to Texas today.

So the Obama campaign officials are stressing that whatever happens on Tuesday, at the end of the day, Senator Obama will still be ahead in delegates, and that is the critical point they really do want to make, even as they hope they get the win that they think really could effectively end the Clinton campaign.
Okay.
NPR's Don Gonyea in San Antonio and NPR's David Greene in Beaumont, Texas.
Thanks to you both.
My pleasure.
Thanks, Melissa
And with me now, our two regular political observers.
E.J.
Dionne of the Washington Post and The Brookings Institution.
Welcome back, E.J.
Mr.
E.J.
DIONNE (Columnist, The Washington Post; Senior Fellow, The Brookings Institution): Thank you.
And David Brooks of The New York Times.
Good to see you again, David.
Good to see you.
David, starting with you.
Mike Huckabee - you heard him there, is he for real?
Is he a serious contender for the nomination right now beyond Iowa?
He is for real.

And as he said, his support is much broader than the evangelical base in part because he's the most normal and natural person for - running for office, which is not saying much, but he is a normal, nice and funny guy.
Running in the field this year.
Right, there are mostly emotional freaks aside from him.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Jonathan Becker, dean of political studies at Bard College.
His article, ""Putin and the Dawn of the New Authoritarians"" is in The Globalist.
Thanks for joining us.
And this, in fact, is really in contrast to what we know are the facts, that Mexican immigration, in particular, is at a net zero right now.

So that means that there are the same number of immigrants from Mexico returning, or leaving the country, than there is coming in, whereas immigration from Asia, and particularly China, and India, is growing.
And they're coming over here on visas and then just overstaying them.
That's how they remain in the country legally.
That's the pattern, yes.
So some of this rhetoric about building walls and increasing border security is a little out of date in terms of the so-called Latino immigration problem.
Do you think that we don't focus on Asian-Americans as much because they've always been viewed, in a way, as the model minority?
Asian-Americans have the highest income.
They're the best-educated of any racial group in the United States.
It's absolutely right, that there are different ways in which different immigrant groups are perceived by Americans.

And I think that that model minority message is absolutely part of it, that Asian immigrants are somehow better than other immigrants, that they're doing it right, that they're achieving economically, achieving academically.
Even though we know that the statistics show us that that's actually not the case.
There's great diversity in the Asian-American population and labeling them all as model minorities is inaccurate and also misleading.
Do you think this trend is going to change the debate about immigration in America, illegal immigration in particular?

I do because already you see that some of the language in the headlines about Asian immigration - Asians on pace to overtake Hispanic surge of immigration - these code words, these terms, they're very anxiety-producing to those of us who study immigration and who know the history because it wasn't so long ago that Asian immigrants were barred from entering the country, couldn't become naturalized citizens, were considered the yellow peril.
The model minority idea is actually a rather recent invention.
So those of us who know the history are a little concerned the history might repeat itself.
Erika Lee is the author of ""The Making of Asian America."" Thank you so much.
Thank you.
The story of Hugo Chavez is one of a leader who has strived to amass greater personal power within a weak democratic system.
Jonathan Becker is dean and associate professor of political studies at Bard College.
He argues that Hugo Chavez is not the only one who's trying to do that.
He argues that Chavez is part of a new brand of political leaders called new authoritarians.
And Jonathan Becker is here now.
Welcome to the program.
Professor JONATHAN BECKER (Bard College) : Thank you.
Well, what do you mean by new authoritarians?
How do they differ from the old ones?
They differ from the old ones because they're not setting up personal dictatorships or one-party states or purely military regimes.
These are people whose goal is to preserve their rule or strengthen their power.

They want, however, to have domestic and international legitimacy that comes with things like elections, and therefore they hold elections and plebiscites like Chavez did in order to strengthen their power and preserve their rule.
Who are some other examples?
Well, I think that Vladimir Putin, whose party, United Russia, was very successful yesterday in Russia's election.
He's sort of the patron saint of the new authoritarians.
But there's others spread throughout the world, especially in the former Soviet states, Alyev(ph), or Mugabe in Zimbabwe, or others spread throughout the former Soviet states.
Would you put Pervez Musharraf of Pakistan in that breed?
Absolutely, although he's on a different side of the authoritarian curve.
He is actually putting himself up for elections and stepped down from the military as a means of preserving his power.
But absolutely, Musharraf is another case of this person who's seeking democratic legitimacy through elections but at the same time trying to control the process.
So they control the process how?
By rigging the elections or...
No.
Yeah.
There are a number of means, I think.
First of all, it's important to understand that they attempt more subtle means of control.
The favorite method is controlling the television, which in most of these countries is the most important form of communications.
They also often alter electoral processes; that is, they limit the opportunity of other parties to campaign or to be on the ballot, they use vast administrative resources to support their candidates.
They disqualify other people.
It's important to remember, though, that they do accept a certain amount of risk in order to get this legitimacy.
Therefore, for example, Chavez lost this referendum yesterday.
That doesn't mean that Chavez is out of power.
He's still in power until 2012, and it doesn't mean that he's not going to try again to reassert greater power.
But they do accept some degree of uncertainty while using vast resources to support themselves.
And it's worth noting that Chavez until very recently, enjoyed broad popular support.
Vladimir Putin certainly, does.
Yeah.
Many of them are actually popular for a couple of reasons.
In some cases, they've actually done things which the population supports, especially economically.
That's certainly the case in Russia, where Putin took over after the disaster of the Yeltsin years.
And Chavez, through the price of oil, as Putin, has done fairly well for the population as a whole.
But that doesn't mean that they are popular forever, and they want to create circumstances in which they can rule even if their popularity goes down.
You know, dictatorships and authoritarianism, it's obviously nothing new in world politics.
Do you see an increase, though, in the amount, the number of world leaders who are, as you call them, the new authoritarians?
Yeah.
I think there's two important issues here.
First, with the end of the Cold War, now being able to call oneself democratic is almost necessary in the international sphere.

The second thing is, especially since the Color Revolutions of Ukraine - the Orange Revolution in Ukraine, the Rose Revolution in Georgia - the leaders are on edge, and they're realizing that having some competition could put them in greater danger.
